results.title: Edward Albee's A Delicate Balance
results.creator_credit: Edward Albee, Tony Richardson, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Listening carefully to the sharp and witty dialogue is the key to engaging with this dramatic play adapted for the screen. Produced originally on the New York stage by Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder, adapted here for the screen by the playwright Edward Albee. Set in suburban New England, a well-to-do older couple (Katharine Hepburn and Paul Scofield) live their lives in a staid familiarity that can only set in with a long-term relationship. The delicate balance that is their marriage is rocked only by the presence of the wife’s alcoholic sister Claire (Kate Reid) and their melancholic daughter (Lee Remick) dealing with yet another failed marriage. Two friends (Joseph Cotton and Betsy Blair) turn up wanting to stay for good but as a group they work through this to get back the ‘balance’. A Pulitzer Prize winning play, this screen version deals with the notions of family, friendship and love, directed by Tony Richardson.

results.title: Edvard Munch
results.creator_credit: Peter Watkins, Sveriges Radio and Norsk Rikskringkasting
results.brief_description: Watkin’s portrayal of the life and work of the pioneer Norwegian expressionist painter and graphic artist Edvard Munch (1863-1908), combines quasi-documentary and period drama, incorporating meticulous detail to place the artist in a social and historical context. The use of non-professional actors, often communicating directly with the audience by glances into the camera, adds to the immediacy of the dialogue which was written in collaboration with the cast. The resulting film takes the viewer to the heart of the artistic temperament and to the very core of the creative process. In Norwegian and German dialogue with English narration and subtitles. Cast includes Geir Westby and Gro Fraas.

results.title: Education?
results.creator_credit: Chris Noonan, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The possible future choices for education, ranging from the free schools approach to the use of technology as a teaching supplement are examined. This film is not an in-depth analysis of these issues, but rather is a discussion-raiser for teacher or parent groups looking at issues of alternatives in education

results.title: Education: where do we go from here?
results.creator_credit: Ron Rowe and Rowe and Co Communications
results.brief_description: A wide variety of education academics, administrators politicians and teacher-union leaders talk about the increasing irrelevance of education systems. Those interviewed include Barry Jones, Dr. Lawrie Shears, Dr. Ken Mckinnon and Professor Headley Beare.

results.title: Education in Tamagawa
results.brief_description: A survey of the Tamagawa educational project, founded in 1929, just outside Tokyo. Children may enrol in the primary school and leave nineteen years later as graduates of the university. The eductational philosophy encourages the fostering of creativity through self-motivated study and the all-round curriculum includes work on the experimental farm as well as cultural and intellectual activities.

results.title: Education for living
results.brief_description:
Episode number 27 of Series “This Modern Age”.
The main changes and developments in education in Britain are reviewed, with flash-backs to the “bad old days”. The film shows what is being done to provide more and better schools and to train the teachers to service them.
